Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Supporting Social Applications in a Hybrid Architecture with CR-Enabled Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to investigate a number of challenging problems that play critical roles in enhancing the performance of social applications by taking advantage of the benefits brought by integrating cognitive radio networking (CRN) and mobile ad hoc networks (MANET). This research is motivated by the observations of (i) the lack of successful and practical applications of CRN and MANETs, though both have been extensively studied in recent years; and (ii) the benefits of integrating CRN and MANET to launch new and to enhance the performance of existing mobile social applications. In this project, graph theoretical approaches are employed to enable scalable HD video chat, to improve the performance of time-bounded information dissemination, and to enhance the privacy of information sharing among the CR-enabled devices. Moreover, network formation games are exploited to construct social-application-aware network topologies for capacity and performance enhancement; and statistical approaches are adopted to investigate the impact of topology control on social behaviors and vice version.

The expected results of this project include novel methodologies and theories to enhance the performance of existing and to enable new mobile social applications. The success of this project will have strong impact on both the theoretical and the practical aspects of social applications in the foreseen hybrid environment of CRN and MANETs. The research findings will be disseminated through high-quality publications as well as presentations in focused workshops and conferences. The project outcomes will provide guidance to and may be adopted by industry for enhancing service availability and integrity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cognitive Radio Networking (CRN) and Mobile Ad-hoc Networking (MANET) have been extensively studied in recent years, but the number of successful and practical cases is still very limited. Considering that the boom of mobile social networking applications has brought the opportunities to utilize social relationships and mobilities as well as the unique challenges to enable new applications and improve the performance of existing ones, the PIs investigated several fundamental problems over a social-aware hybrid environment by integrating the advances of CRN and MANET so that real-world examples can be set for both domains.

Intellectual Merits: During the entire life of this award, outcome results have been published in more than ten papers. The PIs studied techniques to enable scalable HD video chat applications, to reduce the information dissemination delay and cost, and to enhance the routing privacy by decreasing information leakage in hybrid environments. This project will have strong impact on both the theoretical and the practical aspects of social applications in both CRN and MANET. The proposed novel ideas of cooperative uplink transmission, cost efficient dissemination, information leakage reduction, network formation game, and recasting reliable link definition for topology control, are particularly interesting as they may motivate novel research towards many social network applications. Moreover, the success of the proposed research will have strong intellectual impact on maximizing the utilization of resources by integrating CRN and MANET in the foreseen hybrid environment.

 

Broader Impacts: This project was undertaken by a team of researchers (including 1 female faculty member) and graduate students (including 3 female students and 1 minority student) from the U.S. and Finland. In addition to learning theoretical concepts, the students obtained experiences via experimenting the test-bed for performance evaluations. The outcome of the proposed research will have societal impact on facilitating the spread of CRN and MANET deployment. The approaches used in the project may be adopted by industry and military in their future designs for enhancing the service availability and its integrity. The PIs disseminated the research findings through high-quality publications as well as presentations in focused workshops and conferences.
